greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of odd prime factors of n, counted with repetitions.
comment: Number of parts larger than 1 in the partition with Heinz number n. The Heinz number of an integer partition p = [p_1, p_2, ..., p_r] is defined as Product(p_j-th prime, j=1...r) (concept used by _Alois P. Heinz_ in A215366 as an "encoding" of a partition). Example: a(9) = 2 because the partition with Heinz number 9 (=3*3) is [2,2]. - _Emeric Deutsch_ Oct 02 2015
Totally additive because both A001222 and A007814 are. a(2) = 0, and a(p) = 1 for odd primes p, a(m*n) = a(m)+a(n) for m, n > 1. - _Antti Karttunen_, Jul 10 2020
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537 (first 1000 terms from G. C. Greubel)
example: a(9) = 2 because 9 = 3*3 has 2 odd prime factors. - _Emeric Deutsch_ Oct 02 2015
xref: Cf. A000244 (the first occurrence of each n, and also the positions of records).
results.author: _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Sep 03 2003
